Expectation1: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation1: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: The morning sun filtered through the stained glass as I prepared the altar, my mind already racing ahead. Today was the most significant religious holiday of the year, and the church would soon be filled with expectant faces, all looking to me for guidance and inspiration. As a priest, I knew how much this day meant to the community—my presence was not just expected, it was essential. Yet, my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift at the shelter started in less than an hour. I had promised to help serve breakfast, and though I knew others could cover for me if I was late, I hated the thought of letting the team down. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my congregation needed their priest, but the shelter relied on its volunteers. I stood in the vestry, vestments in hand, heart pounding, torn between two worlds that both needed me, unsure which path to take.
